chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2:1
verses.text: Epistle III.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2:2
verses.text: To Velox, Magister Militium.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2:3
verses.text: Gregory to Velox, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2:4
verses.text: We informed your Glory some time ago that soldiers had been prepared to come to your parts; but, inasmuch as your letter had signified to us that the enemy were collected and were marching hitherward, we for this reason have detained them here.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2:5
verses.text: But now it appears to be advantageous that a certain number of soldiers should be sent to you, whom let thy Glory be careful to admonish and exhort to be prepared for toil.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2:6
verses.text: And, when you find an opportunity, confer with our glorious sons Maurilius and Vitalianus, and do whatever, with the help of God, they may appoint you to do for the advantage of the republic.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2:7
verses.text: And, should you ascertain that the unspeakable Ariulph is making an incursion hitherward or to the parts about Ravenna, do you labour in his rear, as becomes brave men, to the end that your renown may by God's help advance still more in the republic from the quality of your labour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 2:8
verses.text: This, however, before all, we admonish you to do: to release without any delay or excuse the family of Maloin and Adobin, Vigild and Grussing, who are known to be with the glorious Magister militum Maurilius, to the end that the men of the aforesaid Maurilius, when they come to your parts, may without any impediment march along with them.

verses.text: [In Colbert.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:1
verses.text: Epistle VI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:2
verses.text: To the Neapolitans.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:3
verses.text: Gregory to the clergy, nobles, gentry, and commonalty dwelling at Naples.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:4
verses.text: Although the sincere devotion of spiritual sons in behalf of their mother Church needs no exhortation, nevertheless, it ought to be stirred up by letter, lest it should suppose itself slighted.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:5
verses.text: On this account I approach your love with an admonition of paternal charity, that with many tears and with one accord we may render thanks to our Redeemer, who has not suffered you to walk along pathless ways under so perverse a teacher, but has made publicly known the crimes of your unworthy pastor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:6
verses.text: For Demetrius, to wit, who even before had not deserved to be called a bishop, has been found to be involved in transactions to such an extent and of such a kind that, if he had received judgment without mercy according to the character of his deeds, he would undoubtedly have been condemned to a most hard death by both divine and human laws.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:7
verses.text: But since, being reserved for penance, he has been deprived of the dignity of the priesthood, we cannot suffer the Church of God to remain long without a teacher, since it is laid down by canonical rules that, on the death or removal of a pastor, the church should not be long deprived of the priesthood.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:8
verses.text: Wherefore, I have thought it necessary to admonish your Charity by this present writing that neither delay nor the discord which has been wont to generate scandals ensue to hinder your election of a pontiff.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 3:9
verses.text: But seek you out with all care such a person as all by common consent may rejoice in, and as is in no respect rejected by the sacred canons; to the end that the office which the most wicked of men had polluted by his evil administration may be worthily filled and administered by him, whoever he may be, who, by the grace of Christ, and with His approval, shall be ordained.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4:1
verses.text: Epistle VII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4:2
verses.text: To Maximianus, Bishop of Syracuse.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4:3
verses.text: Gregory to Maximianus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4:4
verses.text: We execute more efficiently our heavenly commission, if we share our burdens with our brethren.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4:5
verses.text: For this cause we appoint thee, our most reverend brother and fellow-bishop, to have administration over all the churches of Sicily in the name of the Apostolical See, so that whosoever there is reckoned as being in a condition of religion may by our authority be subject to thy Fraternity, to the end that it may not hereafter be necessary for them to make such long sea-voyages in resorting to us for slight causes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4:6
verses.text: But if by any chance there are matters of difficulty which can by no means be settled by the judgment of thy Fraternity, in these only let our judgment be solicited, that so we may occupy ourselves more efficaciously in greater causes, being relieved from the least.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4:7
verses.text: And be it understood that we give this delegation of authority, not to thy place, but to thy person, because we have learnt from thy past life what we may presume of thee in thy future conduct.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 4:8
verses.text: The month of December, the tenth Indiction.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 5

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 5:1
verses.text: Epistle IX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 5:2
verses.text: To the Neapolitans.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 5:3
verses.text: Gregory to the gentry and commonalty (ordini et plebi) residing at Naples.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 5:4
verses.text: The communication you have addressed to us has made manifest what your opinion is of our brother and fellow-bishop Paulus: and we congratulate you in that your experience of him for a few days has been such that you desire to have him as your cardinal bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 5:5
verses.text: But, since in matters of supreme importance there ought to be no hasty decision, so we, Christ helping us, will arrange after mature deliberation what is to be done hereafter, his character meanwhile, in course of time, having become better known to you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 5:6
verses.text: Wherefore, most beloved sons, obey ye the aforesaid man, if you truly love him, and with devoted minds meet his wishes in peaceful concurrence, to the end that the affection of your mutual charity may so bind you to each other, that the enemy who flies about you raging may find no way through any of you for creeping in to break up your unanimity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 5:7
verses.text: Further, when we shall have perceived the aforesaid bishop offering to God the fruit of souls which we long for, God Himself also approving, we will do afterwards whatever divine inspiration may suggest to our heart, with regard to his person and to your desire.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:1
verses.text: Epistle X.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:2
verses.text: To Paulus, Bishop of Naples.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:3
verses.text: Gregory to Paulus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:4
verses.text: If we administer safely the priestly office which we have received, without doubt both Divine assistance and the affection of our spiritual sons will not be wanting to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:5
verses.text: Wherefore let thy Fraternity take care to shew thyself in all things such that the testimony which the clergy, the nobility, and all the people together, of the city of Naples bears to thee may be strengthened by the increase of thy goodness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:6
verses.text: Thou oughtest, then, so to bind thyself to continual employment in exhorting the aforesaid people that the Divine husbandman may store in his garners the fruit of thy word, which thou shalt have gathered from them by thy labours.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:7
verses.text: But till such time as we shall be able, God revealing to us His will, to deliberate concerning the things which our aforesaid sons request us should be done, we grant leave for clerics to be ordained from the ranks of the laity, and also for manumissions to be solemnly celebrated before thee in the same church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:8
verses.text: Moreover we desire thee to observe without hesitation the customs of the clerical order and of the presbyters  of the above-named church: and do thou also keep such diligent watch in the instruction of the same, that, abstaining from all that is unsuitable or unlawful, they may stand fast, under thy exhortations, ministering with due obedience, in the service of our God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 6:9
verses.text: The month of January, the tenth Indiction.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 7

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 7:1
verses.text: Epistle XII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 7:2
verses.text: To Castorius, Bishop of Ariminum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 7:3
verses.text: Gregory to Castorius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 7:4
verses.text: The illustrious lady Timothea has intimated to us by a petitionary notification, as is set forth below, that she has founded an oratory within the city of Ariminum in a place belonging to her, which she desires to have consecrated in honour of the holy cross.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 7:5
verses.text: And, accordingly, dearest brother, if the said construction is in the jurisdiction of thy city, and if it is known that no body has been buried there, then, after reception in the first place of a legitimate endowment, that is, of two-thirds of her whole property (excepting slaves), of her movables and fixtures and live stock, the usufract being reserved to her for her life, and such endowment having been secured by municipal deeds, thou wilt solemnly consecrate the aforesaid oratory without any public mass, on the condition that no baptistery shall be constructed in the same place in future times, and that thou appoint not a cardinal presbyter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 7:6
verses.text: And if perchance she should prefer having masses said there, let her know that she must ask thy Love for a presbyter, to the end nothing else may be presumed by any other priest whatever.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 7:7
verses.text: Further, thou wilt reverently deposit the holy things she has provided.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:1
verses.text: Epistle XV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:2
verses.text: To Paul, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:3
verses.text: Gregory to Paul, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:4
verses.text: I appointed thy Fraternity to preside for the present over the church of Naples, to the end that thou mightest convert all thou canst to God by persuasive preaching.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:5
verses.text: And, while thou oughtest to be giving thy whole mind to this work, thou art in haste to return before bringing forth this fruit to the Lord, and requestest me to settle the affairs of this same church speedily, my mind being meanwhile by no means unoccupied in this matter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:6
verses.text: But, being desirous of fortifying securely the well-being of this Church, I hold it needful to consider the matter with long continued deliberation, so as to be able to arrange its affairs by the ordination of a worthy whom Christ may reveal to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:7
verses.text: Wherefore let thy Fraternity meanwhile study to watch for the good of souls, so that the opinion I have of thee may be strengthened by the effect of thy working.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:8
verses.text: All thou hast written concerning the deacon Peter has now been made known to us by the ex-consul Theodorus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:9
verses.text: And so, now that I know that he is constant to thee, and, according to thy testimony, studies the advantage of the Church, he ought to be afraid of no one's opposition or enmity, but persevere in benefiting the Church and serving God all the more watchfully as he feels that others have a grudge against him; that so they may have no power at all to injure him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 8:10
verses.text: Moreover, thy Fraternity ought not hereafter to be suspected with regard to him; since no surreptitious proceedings will have effect on me.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:1
verses.text: Epistle XVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:2
verses.text: To Natalis, Bishop of Salona.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:3
verses.text: Gregory to Natalis, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:4
verses.text: I have learnt, dearest brother, from many who have come from thy city that, neglecting thy pastoral charge, thou occupiest thyself wholly in feastings: which report I should not have believed had not my own experience of thy conduct confirmed it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:5
verses.text: For that thou in no wise art intent on reading, in no wise givest attention to exhortation, but art even ignorant of the very use and purpose of ecclesiastical order, there is this in evidence, that thou knowest not how to observe reverence to those who are put over thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:6
verses.text: For, when thou hadst been forbidden in writing by our predecessor of holy memory to retain in thy heart the soreness of thy long displeasure against Honoratus thy archdeacon, and when this had been positively interdicted thee by myself also, thou, disregarding the commands of God, and setting at naught our letters, didst attempt by a cunning device to degrade the aforesaid Honoratus thy archdeacon under colour of promoting him to a higher dignity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:7
verses.text: Thus it was contrived that, he being removed from the post of archdeacon, thou mightest call in another who would have fallen in with thy manner of life, the aforesaid man having, as I think, displeased thee for no other cause but that he prevented thee from giving sacred vessels and vestments to thy relations.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:8
verses.text: Which case both I now, and my predecessor of holy memory formerly, have wished to subject to an accurate investigation; but thou, being conscious of what thou hadst done,  hast put off sending hither a representative instructed for trial of the case.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:9
verses.text: Wherefore let thy Fraternity, even after admonition so often repeated, repent of the error of thy wrongdoing, and restore the aforesaid Honoratus to his post immediately on the receipt of my letter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:10
verses.text: Which if thou shouldest defer doing, know that the use of the pallium, granted thee by this See, is taken from thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:11
verses.text: But if, even when thou hast lost the pallium, thou still persistest in thy contumacy, know that thou art deprived of participation of the body and blood of the Lord.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:12
verses.text: And after this it will be needful for us to enquire more fully into the charges against thee, and to consider with the utmost care and investigation whether thou shouldest retain even thy episcopate.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:13
verses.text: Him also who, against the rule of justice, has consented to be promoted to the place of another we depose from the dignity of the said archdeaconry.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:14
verses.text: And, should he presume any longer to minister in this same office, let him know that he is deprived of participation in holy communion.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:15
verses.text: Do thou, therefore, dearest brother, in no wise provoke us further, lest, having set us at naught when in an attitude of charity towards thee, thou shouldest find us very hard in our severity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:16
verses.text: Having, therefore, restored the archdeacon Honoratus to his place, send to us with speed a person instructed in the case, who may be able to shew to me by his allegations how the matter should be equitably proceeded with.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:17
verses.text: For we have commanded the said archdeacon to come to us, that, having heard the assertions of the parties, we may come to whatever decision may be just and well-pleasing to Almighty God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 9:18
verses.text: For we defend no one on the ground of personal love, but, God helping us, keep the rule of justice, putting aside respect to any man's person.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:1
verses.text: Epistle XIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:2
verses.text: To all the Bishops of Dalmatia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:3
verses.text: Gregory to all the bishops constituted throughout Dalmatia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:4
verses.text: Though desiring to visit your Fraternity frequently through the intercourse of letters, yet, when some special case demands our attention, we wish to take the opportunity of fulfilling two duties at once, so as both to refresh our brotherly souls in the way of visitation and to explain accurately matters that come up for notice, lest ignorance of them should leave the mind confused.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:5
verses.text: Now when our brother Natalis, bishop of the city of Salona, wished to advance the archdeacon Honoratus to the order of the priesthood, who thereupon declined being advanced to a higher order, the latter demanded my predecessor of holy memory, in a petition that he sent, that he should not be so advanced against his will.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:6
verses.text: For he alleged that the thing was attempted, not for the sake of promoting him, but in consequence of displeasure against him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:7
verses.text: Thereupon our predecessor of holy memory addressed letters to Natalis, our brother and fellow-bishop, interdicting him from promoting the archdeacon Honoratus against his will, or retaining in his heart the soreness of the displeasure which he had conceived against him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:8
verses.text: And when we too had laid the same interdiction on the said Natalis, he, not only disregarding the commands of God, but also setting at naught our letters, attempted, it is said, craftily to degrade the aforesaid archdeacon, in a way contrary to custom, under colour of promoting him to a higher dignity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:9
verses.text: Thus it was contrived that, having removed him from the archdeaconry, he might call in another person to minister in the place of the deposed archdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:10
verses.text: Now we think that this Honoratus may have fallen under the displeasure of his bishop on account of having prevented him from giving sacred vessels to his relations: and both my predecessor of holy memory formerly and I now have wished to investigate the case accurately; but he, conscious of what he had done, has put off sending a representative with a view to its trial, lest the truth with respect to his doings might appear.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:11
verses.text: We therefore, now that he has been already so often admonished by letter, and has so far been pertinaciously obstinate, have taken order for his being admonished once more in letters sent to him through the bearer of these presents, to the end that he may, immediately on the arrival of the bearer of these presents, receive the archdeacon Honoratus into his former place.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:12
verses.text: And if, with heart still hardened, he should contumaciously defer restoring him to the said position, we order that for his contumacy so many times exhibited he be deprived of the use of the pallium granted to him by this See.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:13
verses.text: But if, even after loss of the pallium, he should persevere in the same pertinacity, we order him to be debarred from participation in the body and blood of the Lord.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:14
verses.text: For it is right that he should find those severe in justice whom he set at naught when they approached him in charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:15
verses.text: Wherefore neither do we now deviate from the path of justice, which the aforesaid bishop has despised; but, when he whose guilt has by no means been made apparent to us has been restored to his place, we enjoin the bishop Natalis to send to us a person with instructions, who may be able by his allegations to prove to us the right intentions of the said bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:16
verses.text: For we have caused also the said archdeacon to come to us, that, having heard the assertions of both parties, we may  decide whatever may be just, whatever may be well pleasing to Almighty God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 10:17
verses.text: For we defend no one on the ground of personal love, but, God helping us, keep the rule of justice without respect to any man's person.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:1
verses.text: Epistle XX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:2
verses.text: To Antoninus, Subdeacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:3
verses.text: Gregory to Antoninus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:4
verses.text: Honoratus, archdeacon of the Church of Salona, had demanded from my predecessor of holy memory, in a petition that he sent, that he should by no means be forced by his bishop to be advanced against his will, in a way contrary to custom, to a higher order.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:5
verses.text: [Here follows an account of the subsequent proceedings, almost word for word the same as that given in Epistle XIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:6
verses.text: ]  Wherefore we have thought it right to support thy Experience by the authority of this present order, that thou mayest resort to Salona, and at least try by exhortation to induce Natalis, our brother and fellow-bishop, who has been admonished by so many letters, to restore the above-mentioned Honoratus to his place immediately.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:7
verses.text: But if, as has been his wont, he should contumaciously delay doing this, forbid him by authority of the Apostolic See the use of the pallium which has been granted him by this See.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:8
verses.text: But if, even after loss of the pallium, thou shouldest find him persevering in the same pertinacity, thou shalt deprive the said bishop of participation in holy communion.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:9
verses.text: Moreover, him who, against the rule of justice, has consented to be promoted to another man's place we order to be deposed from the dignity of the same archdeaconry.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:10
verses.text: And, if he should presume to minister further in the same place, we deprive him of participation in holy communion.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:11
verses.text: For it is right that he should find those severe in justice whom he sets at naught when approaching him in charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:12
verses.text: Wherefore, when the archdeacon Honoratus has been restored to his place, let the aforesaid bishop, at thy instigation, send to us a person with instructions, who may be able by his allegations to prove to us that the bishop's intention is or has been just.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:13
verses.text: [What follows corresponds exactly with the conclusion of Epistle XIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 11:14
verses.text: ]  As to our brother and fellow-bishop Malchus, thou wilt take care to make him find a surety, that he may come to us as soon as possible, to the end that, without any delay or loitering, he may render us an account of his proceedings, and so be able to return to his own with security.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 12

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 12:1
verses.text: Epistle XXII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 12:2
verses.text: To all the Bishops of Illyricum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 12:3
verses.text: Gregory to all the bishops, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 12:4
verses.text: It both affords us joy for your carefulness, and makes your Fraternity safe in your own ordination, if the order of ancient custom is maintained.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 12:5
verses.text: Since, then, we have learnt from the letters which you have sent to us through the presbyter Maximianus and the deacon Andreas that the consent of all of you and the will of the most serene Prince have concurred in the person of our brother and fellow-bishop John, we feel great exultation that, under God's direction, such a one has been advanced to the office of priesthood as the judgment of all has approved as worthy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 12:6
verses.text: Wherefore, in accordance with your request, we confirm our aforesaid brother and fellow-bishop by the authority of our assent in the order of priesthood wherein he has been constituted, and declare our ratification of his consecration by sending him the pallium.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 12:7
verses.text: And since, according to custom, we have committed to him vicariate jurisdiction in our stead, we must of necessity take the precaution of exhorting your Fraternity that you in no wise hesitate to obey him in matters pertaining to ecclesiastical order and the right course of discipline, or in other things not precluded by canonical decrees; that the soundness of your judgment in electing him may be declared by the obedience which you shew.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:1
verses.text: Epistle XXIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, Bishop of Prima Justiniana in Illyricum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:4
verses.text: It is clearly a manifest evidence of goodness that the consent of all should concur in the election of one person.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:5
verses.text: Since, then, the account which we have received from our brethren and fellow-bishops declared that you are summoned to the position of priesthood by the unanimous consent of the whole council and the will of the most serene Prince, we have rendered thanks with great exultation to Almighty God our Creator, who has made your life and actions so commendable in the past as to bring about (what is exceedingly to your credit) your approving yourself to the judgment of all.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:6
verses.text: With them we also fully agree with regard to the person of your Fraternity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:7
verses.text: And we implore Almighty God that, as His Grace has chosen your Charity, so He would keep you in all respects under His protection.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:8
verses.text: We have sent you the pallium according to custom, and, renewing our commission, we appoint you to act as vicar of the Apostolic See, admonishing you that you so shew yourself gentle to your subjects that they may be provoked to love you rather than to fear you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:9
verses.text: And, if perchance any fault of theirs should require notice, you will be careful so to correct their transgressions as by no means to discard paternal affection from your mind.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:10
verses.text: Be watchful and assiduous in the care of the flock committed to you, and strict in the zeal of discipline, so that the wolf lying in wait may not prevail to disturb the Lord's sheepfold, or have opportunity for deceit, so as to hurt the sheep.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:11
verses.text: Make haste with full purpose of heart to win souls to our God; and know that we have received the name of shepherd not for repose, but for labour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:12
verses.text: Let us, then, shew forth in our work what our name denotes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:13
verses.text: If we weigh with right consideration the prerogative of the priesthood, it will be to those who are diligent and do their duty well for honour, but to those who are negligent assuredly for a burden.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:14
verses.text: For, as this name, in the sight of God, conducts those who labour and are assiduous for the salvation of souls to eternal glory, so in the case of the idle and sluggish it tends to punishment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:15
verses.text: Through our tongue let the people committed to us learn that there is another life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:16
verses.text: Let the teaching of your Fraternity be to them an acceptable spur to urge them on, and your life an example for imitation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:17
verses.text: For your Fraternity's preaching should disclose to them what to love and what to fear, and your efficiency in this way should reap the fruit of eternal retribution.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:18
verses.text: But let your deliberate care especially constrain you never to attempt to make any unlawful ordinations; but, whenever any are promoted to the clerical order, or, it may be, to some higher rank, let them be ordained, not for bribes or entreaties, but for merit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:19
verses.text: In no ordination let any consideration, in any way whatever, surreptitiously reach your Fraternity, lest you should be entangled (which God forbid) in the snares of simoniacal heresy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:20
verses.text: For what shall it profit a man, as the Truth says, if he shall gain the whole word, and lose his own soul (Mark viii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:21
verses.text: 36)? Hence it is necessary for us to look to God in all we do, to despise temporal and perishable things, and to direct the desire of our heart to the good things of eternity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:22
verses.text: Your Holiness's present I was altogether unwilling to accept, since it were very unseemly for us to seem to have received gifts from our plundered and afflicted brethren.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:23
verses.text: But your messengers got the better of me by another argument, proffering it to one from whom your Fraternity's offerings may not be withheld.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 13:24
verses.text: For this you ought before all things to study: how you may provide imperishable gifts to be offered to the coming judge of souls, to the end that He may have respect both to you for your profitable labour, and to us likewise for our exhortation.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 14

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 14:1
verses.text: Epistle XXVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 14:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 14:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 14:4
verses.text: Inasmuch as we have enjoined on our brother and fellow-bishop Paulus the work of the visitation of the Neapolitan church, therefore let not Fraternity shrink from assuming the visitation of the Nepesine Church, to the end that, according to the requirements of the Paschal festivity, whatever the solemnity of divine service demands may, through thy operation, be in all respects fulfilled.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 14:5
verses.text: Until, then, we may be able to consider what should be done with regard to our aforesaid brother and fellow-bishop, let thy Fraternity strive to shew thyself so skilful and vigilant in all things that the absence of the bishop aforesaid may not at all be felt.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 14:6
verses.text: The month of April, the tenth Indiction.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15:1
verses.text: Epistle XXVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15:2
verses.text: To Rusticiana, Patrician.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15:3
verses.text: Gregory to Rusticiana, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15:4
verses.text: On receiving the epistle of your Excellency I was relieved by the welcome news of your welfare, hoping that the Lord in His mercy may protect and direct your life and doings.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15:5
verses.text: But I wondered much why you have turned from your intention and vow to accomplish a good work in respect of your meditated journey to the holy places, seeing that, when anything good is by the gift of the Creator conceived in the heart, it is needful that it be carried out with quick devotion, lest, while the cunning plotter strives to ensnare the soul, he should afterwards suggest impediments, whereby the mind, weakened by occupations, may fail to carry its desires into effect.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15:6
verses.text: Whence it is necessary that your Excellency should anticipate all impediments that come in the way of pious designs, and gasp after the fruit of good work with all the efforts of your heart, that so you may succeed in living tranquilly in the present world and gaining possession of a heavenly kingdom in the future.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15:7
verses.text: But as to what you have written to us of Passivus having attempted to spread some calumnies against you, consider, on the other hand, that the most pious emperors have not only been unwilling to listen to them, but have also received the author of them roughly; and turn the whole hope of your soul to Him Who powerfully prevents men in this world from doing as much harm as they long to do, that so He may beat back the wicked intentions of men by the opposition of His arm, and Himself mercifully shatter their attempts, as He has been wont to do.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 15:8
verses.text: I entreat that the glorious Lord Appio and the lady Eusebia, the Lord Eudoxius and the lady Gregoria, be greeted in my name through you.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16:1
verses.text: Epistle XXIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16:2
verses.text: To Maurilius and Vitalianus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16:3
verses.text: Gregory to Maurilius and Vitalianus, magistris militum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16:4
verses.text: On receiving your Glory's letters we gave thanks to God that we were assured of your safety; and we greatly rejoiced at your careful provision; and what you wrote about was at once prepared.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16:5
verses.text: But the magnificent Aldio wrote to us after the arrival of your men that Ariulph was already near at hand, and we feared that the soldiers sent to you might fall into his hands.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16:6
verses.text: Yet here also, so far as God may give aid, our son the glorious magister militum has prepared himself against him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16:7
verses.text: But, if the enemy himself should advance hither, let your Glory also, as you have been accustomed to do, accomplish what you can in his rear.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 16:8
verses.text: For we hope in the power of Almighty God, and that of the blessed Peter himself, the Prince of the apostles, on whose anniversary he desires to shed blood, that he may find him also without delay opposed to him.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:1
verses.text: Epistle XXX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:2
verses.text: To Maurilius and Vitalianus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:3
verses.text: Gregory to Maurilius and Vitalianus, magistris militum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:4
verses.text: We have entreated your Glory through our son Vitalianus both by word and letter, charging you to communicate with him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:5
verses.text: But on the eleventh day of the month of January Ariulph sent us this letter which we forward to you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:6
verses.text: Wherefore, when you have read it, see if the people of Suana have stood fast in the fidelity they promised to the republic, and take adequate hostages from them, such as you can rely on; and moreover bind them anew by oaths, restoring to them what you took from them in the way of a pledge, and bringing them to a right mind by your discourses.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:7
verses.text: But, should you quite distinctly ascertain that they have treated with Ariulph about their surrender to him, or at any rate have given him hostages, as the letter of Ariulph which we have forwarded to you leads us to suspect, then (after wholesome deliberation, lest your souls or mine be burdened with respect to our oaths), do ye whatever ye may judge to be of advantage to the republic.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:8
verses.text: But let your Glory so act that neither anything be done for which we could be blamed by our adversaries, nor (which may the Lord avert) anything neglected which the advantage of the republic requires.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 17:9
verses.text: Furthermore, my glorious sons, take anxious heed, since the enemy, so far as I have ascertained, has an army collected, and is said to be stationed at Narina; and if, God being  angry with him, he should resolve to bend his course hitherward, do you plunder his positions so far as the Lord may aid you, or certainly let those whom you send carefully require night-watches, lest news of any sad event should reach us.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:2
verses.text: To Peter, Subdeacon of Sicily.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:3
verses.text: Gregory to Peter, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:4
verses.text: By information received from Romanus the guardian (defensore) I have learnt that the monastery of handmaidens of God which is on the farm of Monotheus has suffered wrong from our church of Villa Nova with respect to a farm belonging to the latter, which is said to have been leased to the said monastery.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:5
verses.text: If this is so, let thy Experience restore to them the farm, and also the payments from the same farm for the two indictions during which thou hast exacted them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:6
verses.text: Moreover, since many of the Jews dwell on the estates of the Church, I desire that, if any of them should be willing to become Christians, some little of their dues be remitted to them, to the end that others also, incited by this benefit, may be moved to a like desire.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:7
verses.text: Cows which are now barren from age, or bulls which appear to be quite useless, ought to be sold, so that at least some profit may accrue from their price.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:8
verses.text: But as to the herds of mares which we keep very unprofitably, I wish them all to be dispersed, and four hundred only of the younger kept for breeding; which four hundred ought to be presented to the farmers—so many to each, to the end that they may make some return to us from them in successive years: for it is very hard for us to spend sixty solidi on the herdsmen, and not get sixty pence from these same herds.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:9
verses.text: Let then thy Experience so proceed that some may be divided among all the farmers, and others dispersed and converted into money.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:10
verses.text: But so arrange with the herdsmen themselves throughout our possessions that they may be able to make some profit by cultivation of the ground.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:11
verses.text: All the implements which, either at Syracuse or at Panormus, can be claimed by the Church must be sold before they perish entirely from age.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:12
verses.text: On the arrival of the servant of God, brother Cyriacus, at Rome I questioned him closely as to whether he had communicated with thee about the receiving of a bribe in the cause of a certain woman.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:13
verses.text: And the same brother says that he had learnt the state of the case from thy telling him, for that he had been commissioned by thee to ascertain who was the person commissioned to pay the bribe.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:14
verses.text: This I believed, and immediately received him familiarly into favour, introduced him to the people and clergy, increased his stipend, placed him in a superior rank among the guardians, praising his fidelity before all, in that he had acquitted himself so faithfully in thy service; and I have consequently sent him back to thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:15
verses.text: But, inasmuch as thou art in great haste, and I, though sick, am desirous of seeing thee, do thou leave some one whom thou hast fully proved to take thy place in the Syracusan district, and thyself make haste to come to me, that, if it should please Almighty God, we may consult together as to whether thou thyself oughtest to return thither or another person should be appointed in thy place.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:16
verses.text: At the same time I have sent Benenatus the notary to occupy thy place in the patrimony in the district of Panormus till such time as Almighty God may ordain what pleases Him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:17
verses.text: I have strongly rebuked Romanus for his levity, because in the Guest-house (xenodochium) which he kept, as I have now discovered, he has been taken up more with his own profits than with [heavenly] rewards.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:18
verses.text: Him, therefore, if it should haply seem good to thee, leave in thy place.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:19
verses.text: See how thou mayest best fortify him, by alarming and admonishing him, that he may act kindly and carefully towards the peasants (rusticos); and shew himself towards strangers and townspeople changed and active.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:20
verses.text: In saying this, however, I am not selecting any person, but leave this to thy judgment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:21
verses.text: It is enough for me to have selected an occupier of thy place in the district of Panormus; and I wish thee to see thyself to providing one for the Syracusan district.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:22
verses.text: When thou comest, bring with thee the moneys and ornaments (ornamenta) on the part, or of the substance of Antoninus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:23
verses.text: Bring also the payments of the ninth and tenth indictions which thou hast exacted, and with them all thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:24
verses.text: Take care, if it should please God, to cross the sea for this city before the anniversary of Saint Cyprian, lest any danger should ensue (which  God forbid) from the constellation which always threatens the sea at that season.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:25
verses.text: Furthermore, I would have thee know that I have no slight compunctions of mind for having been grievously set against the servant of God Pretiosus for no grievous fault of his, and driven him from me, sad and embittered.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:26
verses.text: And I wrote to the Lord bishop requesting him to send the man to me, if willing to do so; but he was altogether unwilling.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:27
verses.text: Now him I ought not to distress, nor can I do so; since, occupied as he is in the causes of God, he ought to be supported by comfort, not depressed by bitterness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:28
verses.text: But the said Pretiosus, as I hear, is altogether distressed because he cannot return to me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:29
verses.text: I, however, as I have said, cannot distress the Lord bishop, who is not willing to send him, and I am doubtful between the two.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:30
verses.text: Do thou then, if in thy little diminutive body thou hast the greater wisdom, manage the matter so that I may have my will, and the Lord bishop be not distressed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:31
verses.text: Yet, if thou see him to be at all distressed, say no more about it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:32
verses.text: I have, however, taken it amiss that he has excommunicated the Lord Eusebius, a man of so great age and in such bad health.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:33
verses.text: Wherefore it is needful for thee to speak privately to the said Lord bishop, that he be not hasty in pronouncing sentences, since cases which are to be decided by sentences must needs be weighed beforehand with careful and very frequent consideration.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:34
verses.text: When the recruiting officers come, who, as I hear, are already raising recruits in Sicily, charge thy substitute to offer them some little present, so as to render them well-disposed towards him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:35
verses.text: But, before thou comest away, give also something, according to ancient custom, to the praetor's officials; but do it by the hands of him thou leavest in thy place, so as to conciliate their favour towards him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:36
verses.text: Also, lest we should seem to them to be at all uncivil, direct thy substitutes to carry out in all respects the orders we have given to thy Experience as to what is to be given to any individuals or monasteries.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:37
verses.text: But when thou comest, we will, with the help of God consider together how these things should be arranged.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:38
verses.text: The three hundred solidi which I sent to be given through thee to the poor I do not think ought to be committed to their discretion.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:39
verses.text: Let them carry out, then, those directions I have spoken of with reference to particular places and persons.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:40
verses.text: Now I remember having written before now to say that the legacies, which, according to the representation of Antoninus the guardian (defensoris), are due from us to monasteries or others, were to be paid as had been appointed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:41
verses.text: And I know not why thy Experience has delayed to accomplish this.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:42
verses.text: Wherefore we desire thee to pay in full our portion of these legacies from the moneys of the church, that when thou comest to me, thou mayest not leave there the groans of the poor against thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:43
verses.text: Bring also with thee at the same time the securities which have been found relating to the substance of the same Antoninus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:44
verses.text: I have learnt on the information of Romanus that the wife of Redemptus, when dying, directed by word of mouth one silver shell to be sold, and the proceeds given to her freedmen, and also left a silver platter to a certain monastery; in respect of both of which bequests we desire her wishes to be fully carried out, lest from the least things we be betrayed into greater sins.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:45
verses.text: Further, I have learnt on the information of the Abbot Marinianus that the building in the Praetorian Monastery is not yet even half completed: which being the case, what can we praise for it but thy Experience's fervour? But even now let this admonition rouse thee; and, as far as thou canst, assert thyself in the construction of this same monastery.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:46
verses.text: I said that nothing was to be given them for the cost; but I did not prohibit their building the monastery.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:47
verses.text: But so proceed as to enjoin in all ways on him whom thou mayest depute in thy place at Panormus that he construct this same monastery at the charge of the ecclesiastical revenue, and that I may have no more private complaints from the abbot.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:48
verses.text: Moreover, I have learnt that thou knowest certain things on the farms, even in considerable numbers, to belong to others; but, owing to the entreaty of certain persons or to timidity, thou art afraid to restore them to their owners.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:49
verses.text: But, if thou wert truly a Christian, thou wouldest be afraid of the judgment of God more than of the voices of men.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:50
verses.text: Take notice that I unceasingly admonish thee on this matter; which if thou neglect to set right, thou wilt have also my voice for witness against thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:51
verses.text: If thou shouldest find any of the laity fearing God who might receive the tonsure and become agents under the rector, I give my full con  sent.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:52
verses.text: It will be necessary that letters also be sent to them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:53
verses.text: Concerning the case of the son of Commissus the scholasticus, thou hast taken advice; and it appears that what he claims is not just in law.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:54
verses.text: We are unwilling to burden the poor to their disadvantage; but, inasmuch as he has given himself trouble in this matter, we desire thee to give him fifty solidi, which must certainly be charged in thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:55
verses.text: As to the expense thou hast incurred on the business of the Church in the case of Prochisus, either reimburse thyself there out of his revenues, or, should his revenues be clearly insufficient for the repayment, thou must needs receive what is due to thee here from the deacon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:56
verses.text: But presume not to say anything about Gelasius the subdeacon, since his crime calls for the severest penance even to the end of his life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:57
verses.text: Furthermore, thou has sent me one sorry nag and five good asses.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:58
verses.text: That nag I cannot ride, he is such a sorry one; and those good asses I cannot ride, because they are asses.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:59
verses.text: But we beg that, if you are disposed to content us, you will let us have something suitable.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:60
verses.text: We desire thee to give to the abbot Eusebius a hundred solidi of gold, which must certainly be charged in thy accounts.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:61
verses.text: We have learnt that Sisinnius, who was a judge at Samnium, is suffering from grievous want in Sicily, to whom we desire thee to supply twenty decimates of wine and four solidi yearly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:62
verses.text: Anastasius, a religious person (religiosus), is said to be living near the city of Panormus in the oratory of Saint Agna, to whom we desire six solidi of gold to be given.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:63
verses.text: We desire also six solidi, to be charged in thy accounts, to be given to the mother of Urbicus the Prior.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:64
verses.text: As to the case of the handmaiden of God, Honorata, what seems good to me is this: that thou shouldest bring with thee when thou comest all her substance which evidently existed before the time of the episcopate of John, bishop of Laurinum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:65
verses.text: But let the same handmaiden of God come with her son, that we may speak with her, and do whatever may please God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 18:66
verses.text: The volume of the Heptateuch out of the goods of Antoninus we desire to be given to the Praetorian monastery, and the rest of his books to be brought hither by thee.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:2
verses.text: To Justinus, Praetor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:3
verses.text: Gregory to Justinus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:4
verses.text: The spite of the ancient foe has this way of its own, that in the case of those whom, through God resisting him, he cannot delude into the perpetration of evil deeds, he maims their reputation for a time by false reports.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:5
verses.text: Seeing, then, that a sinister rumour about our brother and fellow-bishop Leo had disseminated certain things inconsistent with his priestly profession, we caused strict and lengthened enquiry to be made as to whether they were true, and we have found no fault in him touching the things that had been said.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:6
verses.text: But, that nothing might seem to be omitted, and that no possible doubt might remain in our heart, we caused him over and above to take a strict oath before the most sacred body of the blessed Peter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:7
verses.text: And, when he had done this, we rejoiced with great exultation that from a proof of this kind his innocence evidently shone forth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:8
verses.text: Wherefore let your Glory receive the aforesaid man with all charity, and shew him reverence such as is becoming towards a priest; nor let any doubtfulness remain in your heart touching the charges from which he has now been purged.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 19:9
verses.text: But it lies upon you so to cleave in all respects to the above-named bishop, that you may be seen fittingly and becomingly in his person to honour God, whose minister he is.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXIV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:2
verses.text: To Maximianus, Bishop of Syracuse.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:3
verses.text: Gregory to Maximianus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:4
verses.text: I remember to have often admonished you to be by no means hasty in passing sentence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:5
verses.text: And lo, I have now learnt that your Fraternity in a fit of anger has excommunicated the most reverend abbot Eusebius.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:6
verses.text: Now I am much  astonished that neither his former conversation, nor his advanced age, nor his long-continued sickness, could turn your mind from wrath.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:7
verses.text: For, whatever his transgression may have been, the very affliction of sickness ought to have sufficed as a scourge for him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:8
verses.text: For to one crushed by divine discipline it was superfluous to add human scourges.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:9
verses.text: But perhaps thou hast been allowed to exceed in the case of such a person, in order that thou mightest become more cautious in the case of others of less account, and ponder long when thou art disposed to smite any one through a sentence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 20:10
verses.text: Yet still comfort this same man with a sweetness proportionate to the fury with which thou hast exasperated him, since it is very unjust that the very persons who have loved thee most should find thee without cause most bitter against themselves.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:2
verses.text: To the Abbot Eusebius.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:3
verses.text: Gregory to Eusebius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:4
verses.text: Let thy Charity believe me that I have been greatly saddened for thy sadness, as though I had myself suffered wrong in thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:5
verses.text: But, when I afterwards learnt that, even after the most reverend Maximianus, our brother and fellow-bishop, had restored thee to his favour and communion, thy Love would not accept communion from him, I then knew that what had been done before was just.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:6
verses.text: The humility of God's servants ought to appear in a time of affliction: but those who lift themselves up against their superiors shew that they scorn to be God's servants.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:7
verses.text: And, indeed, what he once did ought not to have been done; but still it ought to have been taken by thee with all humility: and again, when he restored to thee his favour, he ought to have been met with thanks.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:8
verses.text: And because it was not so done by thee, I feel that to us in every way there is cause for tears.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:9
verses.text: For it is no great thing for us to be humble to those by whom we are honoured; for even any worldly man would do this: but we ought especially to be humble to those at whose hands we suffer.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:10
verses.text: For the Psalmist says, See my humility before mine enemies (Psal.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:11
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:12
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:13
verses.text: What life are we leading, if we will not be humble even to our fathers? Wherefore, most beloved son, I beseech thee that all bitterness pass away from thy heart, lest perchance the end should be near, and the ancient foe should, through the iniquity of discord, bar against us the way to the eternal kingdom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 21:14
verses.text: Further, we have caused a hundred solidi to be given to thy Love through Peter the subdeacon, which I beg thee to accept without offence.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop of Squillacium (Squillace, in Calabria).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:4
verses.text: The care of our pastoral office warns us to appoint for bereaved churches bishops of their own, who may govern the Lord's flock with pastoral solicitude.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:5
verses.text: Accordingly we have held it necessary to appoint thee, John, bishop of the civitas Lissitana (Lissus, hodie, Alessio?), which has been captured by the enemy, to be cardinal in the Church of Squillacium, that thou mayest carry on the cure of souls once undertaken by thee, having regard to future retribution.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:6
verses.text: And although, being driven from thine own Church by the invading enemy, thou must govern another Church which is now without a shepherd, yet it must be on condition that, in case of the former city being set free from the enemy, and under the protection of God restored to its former state, thou return to the Church in which thou wast first ordained.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:7
verses.text: If, however, the aforesaid city continues to suffer under the calamity of captivity, thou must remain in this Church wherein thou art by us incardinated.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:8
verses.text: Moreover, we enjoin thee never to make unlawful ordinations, or allow any bigamist, or one who has taken a wife who was not a virgin, or one ignorant of letters, or one maimed in any part of his body, or a penitent, or one liable to any condition of service, to attain to sacred orders.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:9
verses.text: And, shouldest thou find any of this kind, thou must not dare to advance them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:10
verses.text: Africans generally, and unknown strangers, applying for ecclesiastical orders, on no account accept seeing that some Africans are Manichaeans, and some have been rebaptized; while many strangers, though being in minor orders, are proved to have pretended to a higher dignity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:11
verses.text: We also admonish thy Fraternity to watch wisely over the souls committed to thee, and to be more intent on winning souls than on the profits of the present life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 22:12
verses.text: Be diligent in keeping and disposing of the goods of the Church, that the coming Judge, when He comes to judge, may approve thee as having in all respects worthily executed the office of shepherd which thou hast taken upon thee.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:1
verses.text: Epistle XLI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:2
verses.text: To Castorius, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:3
verses.text: Gregory to Castorius, Bishop of Ariminum (Rimini).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:4
verses.text: What lamentable supplications have been poured out to us by Luminosus, abbot of the  monastery of St.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:5
verses.text: Andrew and St.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:6
verses.text: Thomas, in the city of Ariminum, appears from the text of the subjoined petition.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:7
verses.text: With regard to this matter we exhort thy Fraternity that, on the death of the abbot of this same monastery, thy church shall under no pretext interfere in scheduling or taking charge of the property of the said monastery, acquired or to be acquired.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:8
verses.text: And we desire thee to ordain as abbot of the same monastery none other but him whom the whole congregation may by common consent demand as being worthy in character and apt for monastic discipline.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:9
verses.text: Moreover, we entirely forbid public masses to be celebrated there by the bishop, lest occasion be given for popular assemblies in the retreats of God's servants, and also lest too frequent an entrance of women be a cause of scandal (which God forbid), especially to the simpler souls.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:10
verses.text: Further, we ordain that this paper by us written shall be carefully held to, and kept in force and unadulterated in all future time by thee and the bishops that shall be ordained after thee; that so, with the help of God, both thy church may be content with its own rights and no more, and also the said monastery, being subject henceforth to none but general or canonical jurisdiction, and free from all annoyances and vexations, may accomplish its divine work with the utmost devotion of heart.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:11
verses.text: [In place of the epistle as above given, the following, with the appended paper on the privileges of monasteries, is found in some Codices.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:12
verses.text: ]  Gregory to Castorius, Bishop of Ariminum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:13
verses.text: What lamentable supplications Luminosus, abbot of the monastery of Saints Andrew and Thomas, in the city of Ariminum, has poured out to us, appears from the text of the subjoined petition.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:14
verses.text: For from his account we learn that in very many monasteries the monks have suffered many prejudices and annoyances from prelates.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:15
verses.text: It is therefore the duty of thy Fraternity to make provision for their future quiet by a wholesome arrangement, to the end that those who have their conversation therein in God's service may, His grace assisting them, persevere with minds free from disturbance.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:16
verses.text: But, lest from a custom which ought to be rather amended than continued, any one should presume to cause any kind of annoyance to monks, it is necessary that the things which we have caused to be enumerated below should be so carefully observed by the fraternity of bishops that no possible occasion of introducing disquiet may be found hereafter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:17
verses.text: Of the privileges of Monasteries.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:18
verses.text: We therefore interdict in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, and forbid by the authority of the blessed Peter, Prince of the apostles, in whose stead we preside over this Roman Church, that any bishop or secular person hereafter presume in any way to devise occasions of interfering with regard to the revenues, property, or writings of monasteries, or of the cells or vills thereto appertaining, or have recourse to any tricks or exactions: but, if any case should by chance arise as to land disputed between their churches and any monasteries, and it cannot be arranged amicably, let it be terminated without intentional delay before selected abbots and other fathers who fear God, sworn upon the most holy Gospels.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:19
verses.text: Also on the death of the abbot of any congregation, let no stranger be ordained, or any but one of the same congregation whom the society of the brethren shall of its own accord have elected unanimously, and who shall have been elected without fraud or venality.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:20
verses.text: But, if they cannot find a suitable person among themselves, let them in like manner elect some one from some other monastery to be ordained.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:21
verses.text: Nor, when an abbot has been constituted, let any person whatever on any pretext be put over him, unless perchance (which God forbid) crimes be apparent which are shewn to be punishable by the sacred canons.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:22
verses.text: Likewise the rule is to be observed, that monks must not, without the consent of the abbot, be removed from monasteries for constituting other monasteries, or for sacred orders, or for any clerical office.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:23
verses.text: We also disallow ecclesiastical schedules of the property of a monastery to be made by bishops.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:24
verses.text: But if, circumstances requiring it, the abbot of a place should have questions with other abbots concerning property that has come into possession, let the matter be terminated also by their counsel or judgment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:25
verses.text: On the death also of an abbot let not the bishop on any pretext intermeddle in the scheduling or taking charge of the property of the monastery, acquired, or given, or to be acquired.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:26
verses.text: We also entirely forbid public masses to be celebrated by him in a convent, lest in the retreats of the servants of God and their places of refuge any opportunity for a popular concourse be afforded, or an unwonted entrance of women should ensue, which would be by no means of advantage to their souls.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:27
verses.text: Nor let him dare to place his episcopal chair there, or have any power whatever of command, or of holding any ordination, even the most ordinary, unless he should be requested to do so by the abbot of the place; that so the monks may always remain under the  power of their abbots: and let no bishop detain a monk in any church without a testimonial and permission from his abbot, or promote one without such permission to any dignity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 23:28
verses.text: We ordain, then, that this paper by us written be kept to for all future time, in force and unadulterated, by all bishops; that both they may be content with the rights of their own churches and no more, and that the monasteries be subject to no ecclesiastical conditions, or compelled services, or obedience of any kind to secular authorities (saving only canonical jurisdiction), but, freed from all vexations and annoyances, may accomplish their divine work with the utmost devotion of heart.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 24

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 24:1
verses.text: Epistle XLII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 24:2
verses.text: To Luminosus, Abbot.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 24:3
verses.text: Gregory to Luminosus, abbot of the monastery of Saint Thomas of Ariminum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 24:4
verses.text: We were glad to receive thine own and thy congregation's petition, and accede to thy requests, in accordance with the statutes of the Fathers and with form of law.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 24:5
verses.text: For to our brother and fellow-bishop Castorius a letter has been sent by our order, whereby we have taken away entirely from him and his successors all power to harm thy monastery; so that neither may he any longer come among you to be a burden to you, nor schedules be made of the property of the monastery, nor any public procession take place there; this only jurisdiction being still left to him, that he must ordain in the place of a deceased abbot another whom the common consent of the congregation may have chosen as worthy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 24:6
verses.text: But now, these things being thus accomplished, be you diligent in the work of God, and assiduously devote yourselves to prayer, lest you should seem not so much to have sought security of mind for prayer, as to have wished to escape strict episcopal control over you while living amiss.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, Bishop of Ravenna.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:4
verses.text: That I have not replied to the many letters of your Blessedness attribute not to sluggishness on my part, but to weakness, seeing that, on account of my sins, when Ariulph, coming to the Roman city, killed some and mutilated others, I was affected with such great sadness as to fall into a colic sickness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:5
verses.text: But I wondered much why it was that that well-known care of your Holiness for me was of no advantage to this city and to my needs.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:6
verses.text: When, however, your letters reached me, I became aware that you are indeed taking pains to act, but yet have no one on whom you can bring your action to bear.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:7
