verses.text: I therefore attribute it to my sins that this man with whom we are now concerned both evades fighting against our enemies and also forbids our making peace; though indeed at present, even if he wished us to make it, we are utterly unable, since Ariulph, having the army of Authar and Nordulf, desires their subsidies to be given him ere he will deign to speak to us at all about peace.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:8
verses.text: But, as to the case of the bishops of Istria, I have learnt the truth of all you had told me in your letters from the commands which have come to me from the most pious princes, bidding me abstain for the present from compelling them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:9
verses.text: I indeed feel with you, and rejoice greatly in your zeal and ardour, with regard to what you have written, and acknowledge myself to have become in many ways your debtor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:10
verses.text: Know nevertheless that I shall not cease to write with the greatest zeal and freedom on this same matter to the most serene lords.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:11
verses.text: Moreover the animosity of the aforesaid most excellent Romanus Patricius ought not to move you, since, as we are above him in place and rank, we ought so much the more to tolerate with forbearance and dignity any light conduct on his part.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:12
verses.text: If, however, there is any opportunity of prevailing with him, let your Fraternity work upon him, so that we may make peace with Ariulph, if to some small extent we may, since the soldiery have been removed from the city of Rome, as he himself knows.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:13
verses.text: But the Theodosiacs, who have remained here, not having received their pay, are with difficulty induced to guard the walls; and how shall the city subsist, left destitute as it is by all, if it has not peace?  Furthermore, as to the gift redeemed from captivity, about whom you have written to us asking us to enquire into her origin, we would have your Holiness know that an unknown person cannot easily be traced.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:14
verses.text: But as to what you say about one who has been ordained being ordained again, it is exceedingly ridiculous, and outside the consideration of one disposed as you are, unless perchance some precedent is adduced which ought to be taken into account in judging him who is alleged to have done any such thing.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:15
verses.text: But far be it from your Fraternity to entertain such a view.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:16
verses.text: For, as one who has been once baptized ought not to be baptized again, so one who has been once consecrated cannot be consecrated again to the same order.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:17
verses.text: But in case of any one's attainment of the priesthood having been accompanied by slight misdemeanour, he ought to be adjudged to penance for the misdemeanour, and yet return his orders.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:18
verses.text: With regard to the city of Naples, in view of the urgent insistance of the most excellent Exarch, we give you to understand that Arigis, as we have ascertained, has associated himself with Ariulph, and is breaking his faith to the republic, and plotting much against this same city; to which unless a duke be speedily sent, it may already be reckoned among the lost.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:19
verses.text: As to what you say to the effect that alms should be sent to the city of the schismatic Severus which has been burnt, your Fraternity is of this opinion as being ignorant of the bribes that he sends to the Court in opposition to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:20
verses.text: And, even though these were not sent, we should have to consider that compassion is to be shewn first to the faithful, and afterwards to the enemies of the Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:21
verses.text: For indeed there is near at hand the city Fanum, in which many have been taken captive, and to which I have already in the past year desired to send alms, but did not venture to do so through the midst of the enemy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:22
verses.text: It therefore seems to me that you should send the Abbot Claudius thither with a certain amount of money, in order to redeem the freemen whom he may find there detained in slavery for ransom, or any who are still in captivity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:23
verses.text: But, as to the sum of money to be thus sent, be assured that whatever you determine will please me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:24
verses.text: If, moreover, you are treating with the most excellent Romanus Patricius for allowing us to make peace with Ariulph, I am prepared to send another person to you, with whom questions of ransom may be better arranged.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:25
verses.text: Concerning our brother and fellow-bishop Natalis I was at one time greatly distressed, in that I had found him acting haughtily in certain matters; but, since he has himself amended his manners, he has overcome me and consoled my distress.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:26
verses.text: In connexion with this matter admonish our brother and fellow-bishop Malchus that before he comes to us he render his accounts, and then depart elsewhere if it is necessary.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 25:27
verses.text: And if we find his conduct good, it will perhaps be necessary for us to restore to him the patrimony which he had charge of.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:2
verses.text: To Dominicus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:3
verses.text: Gregory to Dominicus, Bishop of Carthage.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:4
verses.text: We have received with the utmost gratification the letters of your Fraternity, which have reached us somewhat late by the hands of Donatus and Quodvultdeus, our most reverend brethren and fellow-bishops, and also Victor the deacon with Agilegius the notary.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:5
verses.text: And though we thought that we had suffered loss from the tardiness of their coming, yet we find gain from their more abundant charity; seeing that from this delay in point of time there appears no interruption, but rather increase of the love which, by the mercy of God, through your contemplation of the priestly office, your practice of reading, and your maturity of age, we know to be already firmly planted in you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:6
verses.text: For it would not flow so largely from you, had it not very many most abundant veins in your heart.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:7
verses.text: Let us, therefore, most holy brother, hold fast with unshaken firmness this mother and guard of virtues.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:8
verses.text: Let not the tongues of the deceitful  diminish it in us, or any snares of the ancient enemy corrupt it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:9
verses.text: For this joins what is divided, and keeps together what is joined.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:10
verses.text: This lifts up what is lowly without tumour; this brings down what is lifted up without dejection.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:11
verses.text: Through this the unity of the universal Church, which is the knitting together of the Body of Christ, rejoices in its several parts through the mind's equalization of them, though having in it dissimilarity from the diversity of its members.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:12
verses.text: Through this these members both exult in the joy of others, though in themselves afflicted, and also droop for the sorrows of others, though in themselves joyful.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:13
verses.text: For seeing that, as the teacher of the Gentiles testifies, if one member suffers anything, the other members suffer with it, and if one member glories, all the members rejoice with it, I doubt not that you groan for our perturbation, as it is quite certain that we rejoice for your peace.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:14
verses.text: Now as to your Fraternity rejoicing with us on our ordination, it displays to me the affection of most sincere charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:15
verses.text: But I confess that a force of sorrow strikes through my soul from contemplation of this order of ministry.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:16
verses.text: For heavy is the weight of priesthood; seeing that it is necessary for a priest, first to live so as to be an example to others, and then to be on his guard not to lift up his heart because of the example which he shews.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:17
verses.text: He should ever be thinking of the ministry of preaching, considering with most intense fear how that the Lord, when about to depart to receive for Himself a kingdom, and giving talents to His servants, says, Trade ye till I come (Luke xix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:18
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:19
verses.text: Which trading surely we carry on only if by our living and our speaking we win the souls of our neighbours; if by preaching the joys of the heavenly kingdom we strengthen all that are weak in divine love; if by terribly sounding forth the punishments of hell we bend the froward and the timid; if we spare no one against the truth; if, given to heavenly friendships, we fear not human enmities.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:20
verses.text: And indeed it was in thus shewing himself that the Psalmist knew that he had offered a kind of Sacrifice to God, when he said, Did I not hate them, O God, that hated thee, and was I not grieved with thine enemies! Yea I hated them with a perfect hated, and they became enemies unto me (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:21
verses.text: cxxxviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:22
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:23
verses.text: But in view of this burden I tremble for my infirmity, and look to the returning of the Master of the house, after receiving His kingdom, to take account of us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:24
verses.text: But with what heart shall I bear His coming, if from the trading I undertook I render Him no gain, or almost none? Do thou, therefore, most dear brother, help me with thy prayers; and what thou seest me to fear for myself, consider daily on thine own account with anxious dread.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:25
verses.text: For through the bond of charity both what I say of myself is thy concern, and what I desire thee to do is mine.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:26
verses.text: Further, as to what your Fraternity writes about ecclesiastical privileges, keep to this without any hesitation, since, as we defend our own rights, so we observe those of several churches.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:27
verses.text: Nor do I through partiality grant to any Church whatever more than it deserves, nor do I under the instigation of ambition derogate from any what belongs to it by right; but I desire to honour my brethren in all ways, and study accordingly that each may be advanced in honour, so long as there can be no opposition to it of right on the part of one against the other.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:28
verses.text: Further, I greatly rejoice with you in the manners of your messengers, in whom it has been shewn me how much you love me, in that you have sent to me elect brethren and sons.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 26:29
verses.text: Given the tenth of the Kalends of August, tenth indiction.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:1
verses.text: Epistle XLVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:2
verses.text: To Columbus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:3
verses.text: Gregory to Columbus, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:4
verses.text: It is known, most dear brother in Christ, that the ancient enemy, who by cunning persuasion deposed the first man from the delights of Paradise to this life of care, and in him even then inflicted the penalty of mortality on the human race, does now with the same cunning, so as more easily to seize the flock, endeavour to infect the shepherds of the Lord's sheep with infused poisons, and already to claim them as his own by right.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:5
verses.text: But we, who, though unworthy, have undertaken the government of the Apostolic See in the stead of Peter the prince of the apostles, are compelled by the very office of our pontificate to resist the general enemy by all the efforts in our power.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:6
verses.text: Now the bearers of these presents, Constantius and Mustellus, have in a petition presented to us given us to understand, and the deacons of the Church of Pudentiana constituted in the province of Numidia assert, that Maximianus, prelate of the same Church, corrupted by a bribe from the Donatists, has by a new licence allowed a bishop to be made in the place where he lives; which thing, though previous usage allowed it,  is prohibited from remaining and continuing by the catholic faith.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:7
verses.text: On this account, then, we have deemed it necessary to exhort thy Fraternity by these present writings that, when Hilarus our chartularius comes to thee, this same case be subjected to a thorough and wise investigation in an united general council of bishops, having the terror of the coming judge before their eyes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:8
verses.text: And if this charge should be proved with sufficient evidences by the bearers of these presents against the aforesaid bishop, let him by all means be degraded from the dignity and office which he enjoys, that both he may return to the gains of penitence through acknowledgment of his fault, and others may not presume to attempt such things.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:9
verses.text: For it is right that one who has sold our Lord Jesus Christ to a heretic for money received, as is said to have been done, should be removed from handling the mysteries of His most holy body and blood.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:10
verses.text: Further, if, apart from this accusation, there is any contest afoot among them, as is contained in the petition of the deacons themselves, with respect to certain wrongs or private transactions, this let thy Fraternity with our aforesaid chartularius fully enquire into with evidence adduced, and decide it according to justice between all the parties.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:11
verses.text: But, further, we have learnt through the information given us by the bearers of these presents that the heresy of the Donatists is for our sins spreading daily, and that very many, leave being given them through venality, are being baptized a second time by the Donatists.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:12
verses.text: How serious a matter this is, brother, it behoves us with the whole bent of our minds to consider.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:13
verses.text: Lo, the wolf tears the Lord's flock, no longer stealthily in the night, but in the open light; and we see him advance in the slaughter of the sheep, and with no solicitude, with no darts of words, do we oppose him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:14
verses.text: What fruits, then, of a multiplied flock shall we shew to the Lord, if even that of which we have undertaken the feeding we see with easy mind mangled by the wild beast? Let us therefore study to inflame our hearts by imitation of earthly shepherds, who often keep watch through winter nights, pinched with showers and frost, lest even one sheep, and perchance not a profitable one, should perish.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:15
verses.text: And, if the prowler should have bitten it with greedy mouth, how do they busy themselves, with what palpitations of heart do they pant, with what cries do they leap forward to rescue the captured sheep, stimulated by the pressing need, lest anything lost through their carelessness should be required of them by the Lord of the flock! Let us then watch, lest anything should perish: and, if anything should by chance have been seized, let us bring it back to the Lord's flock by the cries of divine discourses, that He who is the Shepherd of shepherds may mercifully vouchsafe to approve us in His judgment as having kept watch over His sheepfold.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:16
verses.text: This also it is needful for you to attend to wisely; that, if there should be any proper petition on the part of the same bishop against the bearers of these presents, it should be thoroughly enquired into; and, if haply they themselves also should rightly deserve to be smitten for their own fault, we pronounce that they should by no means be spared on the ground of their having had the toil of resorting to us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 27:17
verses.text: In the month of August, tenth indiction.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:1
verses.text: Epistle XLIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:2
verses.text: To Januarius, Archbishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:3
verses.text: Gregory to Januarius, archbishop of Caralis (Cagliari).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:4
verses.text: If with integrity of heart we consider the priestly office which we administer, the concord of personal charity ought so to unite us with our sons that, as we are fathers in name, so we should be proved by our affection to be so in deed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:5
verses.text: While, then, we ought to be such as has been said above, we wonder why such a mass of complaints has arisen against thy Fraternity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:6
verses.text: We still indeed hesitate to believe it: but, that we may be able to ascertain the truth, we have sent to your parts John the notary of our See, supported by our injunction, who may compel all parties to abide the judgment of chosen arbitrators, and by his own execution carry their judgments into effect.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:7
verses.text: Wherefore we exhort thy Fraternity by this present writing to consider well with thyself beforehand the merits of the cases; and, if you find that you have taken or hold anything unjustly, in consideration of your priesthood to restore it before trial.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:8
verses.text: Now, among numerous complaints, the most distinguished Isidore has complained of having been excommunicated and anathematised by thy Fraternity for invalid reasons.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:9
verses.text: And, when we had wished to learn from one of thy clergy who was here for what cause this had been done, he gave us to understand that it had been done for no other cause than that the man had done thee an injury.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:10
verses.text: This distresses us exceedingly; since, if it is so, thou shewest that thou dost not think of heavenly things, but givest signs of having thy conversation among things of earth, having brought to bear  the malediction of anathema to avenge a private wrong; which is a thing forbidden by the sacred rules.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:11
verses.text: Wherefore for the future be thoroughly circumspect and careful, and presume not to inflict any such penalty again for vindication of thine own wrongs.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 28:12
verses.text: For, shouldest thou do anything of the kind, know that it will afterwards be avenged on thyself.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:1
verses.text: Epistle LI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:2
verses.text: To All Bishops.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:3
verses.text: Gregory to all bishops in the matter of the Three Chapters.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:4
verses.text: I have received your letters with the utmost gratification: but I shall have far abundant joy, if it should be my lot to rejoice in your return from error.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:5
verses.text: Now the forefront of your Epistle notifies that you suffer severe persecution.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:6
verses.text: But persecution, if endured irrationally, is of no profit at all unto salvation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:7
verses.text: For it is impious in any one to expect a recompense of reward for sin.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:8
verses.text: For you ought to know, as the blessed Cyprian says, that it is not the suffering that makes the martyr, but the cause for which he suffers.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:9
verses.text: This being so, it is exceedingly incongruous for you to glory in the persecution whereof you speak, seeing that you are not thereby at all advanced towards eternal rewards.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:10
verses.text: Let, then, purity of faith bring your Charity back to your mother church who bare you; let no bent of your mind dissociate you from the unity of concord; let no persuasion deter you from seeking again the right way.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:11
verses.text: For in the synod which dealt with the three chapters it is distinctly evident that nothing pertaining to faith was subverted, or in the least degree changed; but, as you know, the proceedings had reference only to certain individuals; one of whom, whose writings evidently deviated from the rectitude of the Catholic Faith, was not unjustly condemned.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:12
verses.text: Moreover, as to what you write about Italy among other provinces having been especially scourged since that time, you ought not to twist this into a reproach, since it is written, Whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom he receiveth (Hebr.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:13
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:14
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:15
verses.text: If, then, it is as you say, Italy has been since that time the more loved by God, and in all ways approved, having been counted worthy of enduring the scourge of the Lord.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:16
verses.text: But, since it is not as ye try to make out by way of insulting over her, attend ye to reason.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:17
verses.text: After the Pope Vigilius of illustrious memory, having been appointed in the royal city, promulgated a sentence of condemnation against Theodora, then empress, or against the Acephali, the city of Rome was then attacked and captured by enemies.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:18
verses.text: Does it follow from this that the Acephali had a good case, or that they were unjustly condemned, because such things happened after their condemnation? Away with the thought! For it is not fit that either any one of you, or any others who have been instituted in the mysteries of the Catholic Faith, should say or in any way acknowledge this.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:19
verses.text: This then being recognized, retire ye even now at length from the determination you have come to.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:20
verses.text: Wherefore, that full satisfaction may be infused into your minds, and all doubt removed, with respect to the three chapters, I have judged it of advantage to send you the book which my predecessor of holy memory, Pope Pelagius, had written on this subject.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:21
verses.text: Which book if you should be willing to read again and again, putting aside the spirit of wilful self-defence, I have confidence that you will follow it in all respects, and, notwithstanding all, return to union with us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:22
verses.text: But if henceforth, after perusal of this book, you should decide to persist in your present determination, you will doubtless shew that you gave yourselves up not to reason but to obstinacy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 29:23
verses.text: Wherefore once more, in a spirit of compassion, I admonish your Charity, that, inasmuch as under God the purity of our faith has remained inviolate in the matter of the Three Chapters, ye put away from you all swelling of mind, and return to your mother the Church, who expects and invites her sons; and this all the more speedily as you know that she expects you daily.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:1
verses.text: Epistle LII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:2
verses.text: To Natalis, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:3
verses.text: Gregory to Natalis, Bishop of Salona.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:4
verses.text: As though forgetting the tenour of former letters, I had determined to say nothing to your Blessedness but what should savour of sweetness: but, now that in your epistle you have recurred in the way of argumentation to preceding letters, I am once more compelled to say perhaps some things that I had rather not have said.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:5
verses.text: For in defence of feasts your Fraternity mentions the feast of Abraham, in which by the testimony of Holy Scripture he is said to have entertained three angels (Gen.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:6
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:7
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:8
verses.text: In view of this example, neither will we blame your Blessedness for feasting, if we come to know that you entertain angels.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:9
verses.text: Again you say that Isaac gave a blessing to his son when satiated (Gen.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:10
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:11
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:12
verses.text: Now as to both these things in the Old Testament—since they were so done in the way of history as still to have a meaning in the way of allegory—would that we could so read through the accounts of the things done as to perceive and take thought for the things to be done.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:13
verses.text: For indeed the one, in saluting one only of the three angels, declared the Persons of the Trinity to be of one Substance; the other blessed his son when satiated, because one who is filled with divine banquets has his senses extended into the power of prophecy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:14
verses.text: But the words of Holy Writ are divine banquets.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:15
verses.text: If, then, you read diligently—if, drawing example from what is outward, you penetrate what is inward—you will be satiated, as it were, from hunting in the field, and fill the stomach of the soul, so as to be able to announce things to come to your son placed before you, to wit to the people you have taken in charge.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:16
verses.text: But one who prophesies anything of God is already in the dark as to this world; for it is assuredly right and fit that he whose senses are bright inwardly through intelligence should see less through concupiscence here below.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:17
verses.text: Take, therefore, these things to yourselves; and, if you know yourselves to be such as I have said, you need not at all doubt of our esteem.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:18
verses.text: I also find your Blessedness rejoicing if you bear the name of "a gluttonous man" along with the world's Creator.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:19
verses.text: As to this I briefly comment thus; that, if you are called so falsely, you do truly bear this name along with the world's Creator; but, if it is true of you, who can doubt that it was false of Him? A like name does not avail to acquit you, if the cause for it is unlike.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:20
verses.text: For even the thief who was condemned to die endured the cross with Him; but a like crucifixion did not acquit him whom his own guilt bound.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:21
verses.text: But now I beseech God with all the prayers I can offer that not the name only, but the cause for it, may join your most holy Fraternity to our Creator.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:22
verses.text: Further, your Holiness in your letters rightly praises feasts which are made with the intention of bestowing charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:23
verses.text: But yet you should know that they then truly proceed from charity, when at them the lives of the absent are not backbitten, no one is censured in derision, and no idle tales about secular affairs, but the words of sacred reading, are heard; when the body is not pampered more than is needful, but only its weakness refreshed, that it may be kept in health for the practice of virtue.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:24
verses.text: If, then, you thus conduct yourselves in your feasts, I own that you are masters of abstinence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:25
verses.text: As to your alleging to me the testimony of the apostle Paul, where he says, Let not him that eateth not judge him that eateth (Rom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:26
verses.text: xiv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:27
verses.text: 3), I think that this was altogether out of place, seeing both that I am not one that eateth not, and also that Paul did not here mean to say that the members of Christ, who are mutually bound to each other in His body, that is to say in his Church, with the bond of charity, should have no care whatever for each other.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:28
verses.text: If, indeed, I had nothing to do with thee, nor thou with me, I should rightly be compelled to hold my peace, lest I should blame one whom I could not mend.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:29
verses.text: This precept, then, was given only with reference to persons who go about to judge those who have not been committed to their care.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:30
verses.text: But now that we, by the ordering of God, are one, we should be much in fault were we to pass over in silence what calls for our correction.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:31
verses.text: Lo, thy Fraternity has taken it amiss to have been blamed by me about feasts, while I, who surpass thee in my position, though not in my life, am ready to be found fault with by all, and by all to be amended.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:32
verses.text: And him only do I esteem to be a friend to me, through whose tongue I wipe off the stains of my soul before the appearance of the strict judge.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:33
verses.text: But as to what you say, most sweet brother, about your being unable to read because of the pressure of tribulations upon you, I think this avails little for your excuse, since Paul  says, Whatsoever things are written are written for our instruction, that we through patience and comfort of the Scriptures might have hope (Rom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:34
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:35
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:36
verses.text: If, then, holy Scripture has been prepared for our comfort, we ought by so much the more to read it as we find ourselves the more wearied under the burden of tribulations.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:37
verses.text: But if we are to rely only on that sentence which you quote in your letter, wherein the Lord says, When they deliver you up, take no thought how or what ye shall speak, for it shall be given you in that hour what ye shall speak; for it is not ye that speak, but the Spirit of your Father that speaketh in you (Matth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:38
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:39
verses.text: 19), I say that Holy Scriptures have been given us in vain, if, being filled with the Spirit, we have no need of external words.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:40
verses.text: But, dearest brother, trusting in God without doubt, when we are straightened in a time of persecution, is one thing; what we ought to do when the Church is at peace is another.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:41
verses.text: For it is our duty, through this same Spirit, to learn by reading now what we may be able to shew forth also in suffering, should cause arise.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:42
verses.text: Now, I rejoice exceedingly that you declare in your letter that you are giving attention to exhortation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:43
verses.text: For thus I know that you are wisely fulfilling the duties of your position, if you take pains to draw others also to your Maker.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:44
verses.text: But your saying in the same sentence that you are not like me saddens me at once, after I had begun to rejoice, since I think that it is in derision that you give me praises which in truth I do not recognize as due.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:45
verses.text: However, I give thanks to Almighty God that through you heretics are being recalled to holy Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:46
verses.text: But it is needful for you to have a care that those also who are contained in the bosom of holy Church live so that they be not her adversaries through their evil lives.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:47
verses.text: For, if they give themselves not to heavenly desires, but to earthly lusts and pleasures, sons of strangers are being nourished in her bosom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:48
verses.text: Now as to your declaring that you cannot possibly be ignorant of the degrees of ecclesiastical rank, I too fully know them with regard to you; and I am therefore much distressed that, if you knew the order of things, you have failed, to your greater blame, in knowing it with regard to me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:49
verses.text: For, after letters had been addressed to your Blessedness by my predecessor and myself in the cause of the archdeacon Honoratus, then, the sentence of both of us being set at nought, the said Honoratus was deprived of the rank belonging to him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:50
verses.text: Which thing if any one of the four patriarchs had done, such great contumacy could by no means have been allowed to pass without the most grievous offence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:51
verses.text: Nevertheless, now that your Fraternity has returned to your proper position, I do not bear in mind the wrong done either to myself or to my predecessor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:52
verses.text: But as to your saying that what has been handed down and guarded by my predecessors ought to be observed in our times also, far be it from me to infringe in any church the statutes of our ancestors with regard to my fellow priests, since I do myself an injury if I disturb the rights of my brethren.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:53
verses.text: But when your accredited messengers arrive, I shall know the rights of the case between you and the aforesaid archdeacon Honoratus; and my own personal examination of it will shew you that, if you have the support of justice on your side, you will sustain no injury from me; as indeed you never have done.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:54
verses.text: But in case justice supports the plea of the often-before-named Honoratus, I will shew by my acquittal of him that in judgment I have no knowledge even of persons whom I knew.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:55
verses.text: Concerning the article of excommunication which, if I may say so, was of necessity added to our letters (though even the second and the third time with a condition interposed), your Blessedness complains unreasonably, since the apostle Paul says, Having in a readiness to revenge all disobedience (2 Cor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:56
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:57
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:58
verses.text: But let these things pass: let us return to what concerns us now.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 30:59
verses.text: For, if the lord Natalis acts as he should do, I cannot but be friends with him, knowing how much I am a debtor to his affection.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:1
verses.text: Epistle LIV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:2
verses.text: Here follows the Epistle of Saint Licinianus, bishop, concerning the Book of Rules, addressed to Saint Gregory, pope of the city of Rome.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:3
verses.text: To the most blessed Lord pope Gregory, Licinianus, bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:4
verses.text: The Book of Rules issued by Thy Holiness, and by the aid of divine grace conveyed to us, we have read with all the more pleasure for the spiritual rules which we find contained in it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:5
verses.text: Who can fail to read that with pleasure wherein by constant meditation he may find medicine for his soul; wherein, despising the fleeting things of this world which vary in their mutability, he may open the eyes of his soul to the settled estate of eternal life? This  book of thine is a palace of all virtues.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:6
verses.text: In it prudence fixes the boundary line between good and evil; justice gives each one his own, while it subjects the soul to God, and the body to the soul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:7
verses.text: In it fortitude also is found ever the same in adversity and in prosperity, being neither broken by opposition nor lifted up by success.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:8
verses.text: In it temperance subdues the rage of lust, and discriminately imposes a limit upon pleasures.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:9
verses.text: In it thou comprehendest all things that pertain to the partaking of eternal life: and not only for pastors layest down a rule of life, but also to those who have no office of government thou suppliest a rule of life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:10
verses.text: For pastors may learn in thy fourfold division what they should be in coming to this office; what life they should lead after coming to it; how and what they should teach, and what they should do to avoid being lifted up in so high a position as that of priesthood.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:11
verses.text: This excellent teaching of thine is attested by the holy ancient fathers, doctors, and defenders of the Church; Hilary, Ambrose Augustin, Gregory Nazianzen: these all bear testimony to thee as did the prophets to the apostles.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:12
verses.text: Saint Hilary says, in expounding the words of the Apostle who was the teacher of the Gentiles, "For so he signifies that the things belonging to discipline and morals serve to the good desert of the priesthood, if those things also which are necessary for the science of teaching and guarding the faith shall not be wanting among the rest; since it does not all at once constitute a good and useful priest only to act innocently, or only to preach knowingly, seeing that, though a man be innocent, he profits himself only unless he be learned, and that he that is learned is without the authority of a teacher unless he be innocent".

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:13
verses.text: Saint Ambrose gives attestation to this book of thine in the books which he wrote about Duties (de officiis).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:14
verses.text: Saint Augustin gives attestation, saying, "In action dignity should not be loved in this life, neither power; since all things under the sun are vain".

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:15
verses.text: But the work itself which is done by means of this dignity or power, if it is rightly and profitably done, this is what avails for that weal of subjects which is according to God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:16
verses.text: Wherefore the Apostle says, "He that desireth the office of a bishop desireth a good work".

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:17
verses.text: He wished to explain what episcopus means; that it is a title denoting work, not dignity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:18
verses.text: For it is a Greek word derived hence;—that he who is put over others overlooks those whom he is put over, to wit, as taking care of them; for episcopacy is overlooking.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:19
verses.text: Therefore, if we choose, we may say in Latin that to exercise the office of a bishop is to overlook; so that one who delights to be over others and not to profit them may understand that he is no bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:20
verses.text: For so it is that no one is prohibited from longing to become acquainted with truth, for which purpose leisure is to be commended; but as to a position of superiority, without which the people cannot be governed, though it may be held and administered becomingly, it is unbecoming to covet it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:21
verses.text: Wherefore charity seeks holy leisure, so as to have time for perceiving and defending the truth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:22
verses.text: But if [the burden of government] be imposed, it is to be undertaken on account of the obligation of charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:23
verses.text: But not even so should delight in the truth be altogether forsaken, lest the former sweetness should be withdrawn, and the present obligation be oppressive (Lib.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:24
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:25
verses.text: de Trinit, num.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:26
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:27
verses.text: Saint Gregory attests, whose style thou followest, and after whose example thou didst desire to hide thyself in order to avoid the weight of priesthood; which weight, of what sort it is, is clearly declared in the whole of thy book: and yet thou bearest what thou wast afraid of.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:28
verses.text: For thy burden is borne upwards, not downwards; not so as to sink thee to the depths, but to lift thee to the stars; whilst by the grace of God, and the merit of obedience, and the efficiency of good work, that is made sweet which seemed to have heaviness through human weakness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:29
verses.text: For thou sayest the things that are in agreement with the apostles and with apostolic men.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:30
verses.text: For, being fair, thou hast said things fair, and in them hast shewn thyself fair.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:31
verses.text: I would not have thee liken thyself to an ill-favoured painter painting fair things, seeing that spiritual teaching issues from a spiritual soul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:32
verses.text: The human painter is by most men esteemed more highly than the inanimate picture.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:33
verses.text: But put not this down to flattery or adulation, but to truth: for it neither becomes me to lie, nor thee to commend what is false.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:34
verses.text: I then, though plainly sincere, have seen thee and all that is thine to be fair, and have seen myself as ill-favoured enough in comparison with thee.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:35
verses.text: Wherefore I thee pray by the grace of God which abounds in thee that thou reject not my prayer, but willingly teach me what I confess myself ignorant of.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:36
verses.text: For we are compelled of necessity to do what thou teachest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:37
verses.text: For, when there is no skilled person found for the sacerdotal office, what is to be done but that an unskilled one such as I am, should be ordained? Thou orderest that no unskilled one should be ordained.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:38
verses.text: But let thy prudence  consider whether it may not suffice him for skill to know Jesus Christ and Him crucified: for, if this does not suffice, there will, according to this book, be no one who can be called skilled: and so no one will be a priest, if none, unless he be skilled, should be one.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:39
verses.text: For with open front we resist bigamists, lest the sacrament should be thus corrupted.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:40
verses.text: What if the husband of one wife should have touched a woman before his wife? What if he should not have had a wife, and yet should not have been without touch of a woman? Comfort us with thy pen, that we may not be punished either for our own sin or that of others.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:41
verses.text: For we are exceedingly afraid lest we should be forced to do what we ought not to do.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:42
verses.text: Lo, obedience must be paid to thy precepts, that such a one may be made a priest as apostolical authority approves; and such a one as is sought is not found.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:43
verses.text: Thus faith will cease which cometh of hearing; baptism will cease, if there should be no one to baptize; those most holy mysteries will cease which are effected through priests and ministers.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:44
verses.text: In either case danger remains: either such a one must be ordained as ought not to be, or there must be no one to celebrate or administer sacred mysteries.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:45
verses.text: A few years ago Leander, Bishop of Hispalis, on his return from the royal city, saw us in passing, and told us that he had some homilies issued by your Blessedness on the Book of Job.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:46
verses.text: And, as he passed by in haste, he did not shew them to us as we requested.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:47
verses.text: But thou wrotest afterwards to him about trine immersion, and saidest in thy letter, as I am told, that thou wast dissatisfied with that work, and hadst determined on maturer consideration to change those homilies into the form of a treatise.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:48
verses.text: We have indeed six books of Saint Hilary, Bishop of Pictavia, which he turned into Latin from the Greek of Origen: but he has not expounded the whole of the book of holy Job in order.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:49
verses.text: And I am not a little surprised that a man so very learned and so holy should translate the silly tales of Origen about the stars.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:50
verses.text: I, most holy father, can in no wise be persuaded to believe that the heavenly luminaries are rational spirits, Holy Scripture not declaring them to have been made either along with angels or along with men.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:51
verses.text: Let then your Blessedness deign to transmit to my littleness not only this work, but also the other books on morals which in this Book of Rules thou speakest of having composed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:52
verses.text: For we are thine, and are delighted to read what is thine.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:53
verses.text: For to me it is a desirable and glorious thing, as thy Gregory says, to learn even to extreme old age.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles II 31:54
verses.text: May God the Holy Trinity vouchsafe to preserve your crown unharmed for instructing His Church, as we hope, most blessed father.
